byline.contributor: Tim Arango contributed reporting from Istanbul, and Mari-Leena Kuosa from Finland.

abstract: Arrests of twin refugee brothers from Iraq in Finland by authorities due to their suspected involvement in Islamic State group massacre of Iraqi Army recruits in Tikrit in 2014 has highlighted complexity of prosecuting such criminal cases; case, along with similar one in Sweden, has shown how marshalling of evidence is extremely difficult, despite penchant of Islamic State to record videos of atrocities.
lead_paragraph: Two refugees have been held in connection with an ISIS massacre near Tikrit, based on a video, but even with such evidence, it’s a challenge to hold suspects accountable for atrocities.

headline.main: Iraqis’ Arrest in Finland Highlights Difficulties in Prosecuting Distant Crimes
headline.print_headline: Finnish Courts Find ISIS Case at the Doorstep

snippet: Two refugees have been held in connection with an ISIS massacre near Tikrit, based on a video, but even with such evidence, it’s a challenge to hold suspects accountable for atrocities.
